channel.title: Building 6 PCs - $8,850 budget
channel.description:
My school is giving me (well, not giving me, but you get the point) $8,850 to build 6 brand new PCs from scratch, which equals out to precisely $1,475 per computer. I must find the best quality parts and stay inside the budget. Each part needs to be the best as possible so it performs well, lasts a long time, and very reliable. I will be giving the school board a presentation which will have the following information about each part:
1. Reliability rating & source 2. Warranty 3. Product description 4. Product specification relevant to the decision process 5. Why I chose each part
Here's the part where I need you. I need to find appropriate parts for these builds. These machines will be going into the school's Digital Media classroom, and will need to run many Adobe programs etc. This is why the parts need to be reliable. Anywho, this is the list of parts needed:
Power Supply
Monitor
Keyboard & Mouse
Case
Motherboard
Graphics Card
RAM
CPU
Optical Drive (CD/DvD)
HDD or SSD (leaning towards a SSD, what are your opinions? Note: mostly all the data is stored on the network. Huge amounts of disk space is not needed, and is considered overkill.)
Operating system (Already made this choice. Sticking with Windows 7 64 bit business)
So, if you don't know what I need help on, it's finding the right parts for these builds. All I need is the best part for each part, while staying inside the budget. Also, when showing me a part, please tell me the reason why you choose that part. I'm not asking you to do this entire job for me, just give me some hints and tips for parts. Any questions? Ask.

@Travas wrote:

item.title: Building 6 PCs - $8,850 budget
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

Yeah, with a SSD I wouldn’t expect to get ridiculous amounts of space anyways. I would just buy one with high transfer speeds.

The IT computer at my job has 2 of these. Pretty fast, but again, I’ve never really used another SSD. I’m going to have to get one for my computer though because they’re so much faster.

newegg.com

Intel 520 Series Cherryville 2.5" 120GB SATA III MLC Internal Solid State...

Buy Intel 520 Series Cherryville 2.5" 120GB SATA III MLC Internal Solid State Drive (SSD) SSDSC2CW120A3K5 with fast shipping and top-rated customer service.Once you know, you Newegg!

What SSD do you recommend? Remember, I don’t need a lot of storage. 120GB each would do great.

item.description:

i7, gtx 660, solid state hard drive (Don’t cheap out here), 8 gb RAM.

item.title: Building 6 PCs - $8,850 budget
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

These builds need graphics cards, no doubt about that.

Read full topic

item.title: Building 6 PCs - $8,850 budget
item.dc:creator: @chillwitm888 chillwitm888
item.description:
@chillwitm888 wrote:

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:28, topic:475083”]I’d recommend these base specs…

  • RAM: 6gb + of RAM (8gb would work even better.)
  • PROCESSOR: 3.4gHz - 3.6 gHz (Intel I would recommend, though others are good, such as AMD.) At least quad core, if you’re wanting to use it for digital media.
  • HARD DRIVE: I’d recommend 700gb, which is plenty for their usage.
  • VIDEO CARD: You don’t need an over-done, gaming video card. A basic nVidia $100-$140 video card will work (check their site.)

I can recommend good Mice, Keyboards, Monitors, etc. Or are you just building the towers?[/quote]
No, honestly, I think Video Cards matter more than Cpus
Besides, if you are just getting a cheap 100 dollar video card
you might be better off without a video card and use the integrated intel 4000 or 3000w/e
I WOULD strongly suggest you get a 150$ or more DEDICATED Video Card

Read full topic

item.title: Building 6 PCs - $8,850 budget
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:30, topic:475083”]AMD makes great processors, I don’t see why people love bashing them.

My A8-5600k I just got works flawlessly.[/quote]I did look into that processor (http://www.cpubenchmark.net/cpu.php?cpu=AMD+A8-5600K+APU) but I have an Intel board so I’m sticking with Intel. Thanks though.

item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

I’d recommend these base specs…

  • RAM: 6gb + of RAM (8gb would work even better.)
  • PROCESSOR: 3.4gHz - 3.6 gHz (Intel I would recommend, though others are good, such as AMD.) At least quad core, if you’re wanting to use it for digital media.
  • HARD DRIVE: I’d recommend 700gb, which is plenty for their usage.
  • VIDEO CARD: You don’t need an over-done, gaming video card. A basic nVidia $100-$140 video card will work (check their site.)

I can recommend good Mice, Keyboards, Monitors, etc. Or are you just building the towers?

Get to the next level with the EVGA GeForce GTX 680. This card delivers truly game-changing performance that taps into the powerful new GeForce architecture to redefine smooth, seamless, lifelike gami ...


if you dont wanna spend 400 on a gfx card then get the 660 ti
230$ 256gb SSD non refurbished
newegg.com

OCZ Vertex 4 2.5" 128GB SATA III MLC Internal Solid State Drive...

Buy OCZ Vertex 4 2.5" 128GB SATA III MLC Internal Solid State Drive (SSD) VTX4-25SAT3-128G with fast shipping and top-rated customer service.Once you know, you Newegg!

lol if u want a good cheap i3s you can get one cheap with hyperthreading (makes windows read dual core i3 as a quad core cpu)

item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

for the love of god don’t buy a $160 case

get a high end i7 processor YOU WILL NEED THE EXTRA PROCESSING POWER FOR VIDEO PROCESSING, THESE HIGH END DESKTOP PROCESSORS ARE DESIGNED FOR VIDEO PROCESSING NOT FOR GAMING, get a mid to high end graphics card from a good manufacturer, get 16gb of cheap ram (hint: 1600mhz ddr3 is good and cheap)

spend the rest of the money on decent monitors
